titleStmt.title: The last newes from Ireland being a true relation of all most remarkable occurrences which hath lately happened concerning the state of that oppressed and distracted kingdome : sent over from Ireland to one Master Dobbins in London : as also the view and consideration of some Scotch forces which were sent over for the supply of Ireland to be under the command of Sir William Belfore, late Lieutenant of the Tower in London : together with a list of the field-officers chosen and appointed for the Irish expedition, by the committee at Guild-Hall London, for the regiments of 5000 foot, and 500 horse under the command of Philip Lord Wharton, Baron of Scarborough, Lord Generall of Ireland.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 13KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The last newes from Ireland being a true relation of all most remarkable occurrences which hath lately happened concerning the state of that oppressed and distracted kingdome : sent over from Ireland to one Master Dobbins in London : as also the view and consideration of some Scotch forces which were sent over for the supply of Ireland to be under the command of Sir William Belfore, late Lieutenant of the Tower in London : together with a list of the field-officers chosen and appointed for the Irish expedition, by the committee at Guild-Hall London, for the regiments of 5000 foot, and 500 horse under the command of Philip Lord Wharton, Baron of Scarborough, Lord Generall of Ireland.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for I. Green and A. Coe,

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in Bodleian Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

revisionDesc.change: 2014-05 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2015-02 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: The Last NEWES FROM IRELAND BEING A TRUE RELATION OF ALL most remarkable Occurrences which hath lately happened concerning the state of that oppressed and distracted Kingdome.
Sent over from Ireland to one Master Dobbins in LONDON.
As also the view and consideration of some Scotch Forces which were sent over for the supply of Ireland to be under the Command of Sir William Belfore, late Lieutenant of the Tower in London.

TOGETHER WITH A LIST OF THE FIELD-Officers chosen and appointed for the Irish Expedition, by the Committee at Guild-hall London, for the Regiments of 5000. foot, and 500. horse Under the command Philip Lord Wharton Baron of Scarborough, Lord Generall of Ireland.
June 13. London, Printed for I. Green. and A. Coe. 1642.

YOur Countrey-man Henry Barnsley, Sir Nicholas Whites Priest, stands indicted at the Kings Bench for Treason, but it will be Michaelmas Tearme before the formalities of the Law wil be compleated to have him out-lawed; if in the meane time you desire a Copie of the Indictment, you may have it, but I conceive it can availe little untill hee bee sued to an Outlary.

Captaine Sterling, who was Garrisond at Dunslagan below Dubbor, being one Friday last invited with his Lieutenant and Arch-deacon Watson, by one Dillon in the County of Meath (who had a protection from the State) to dinner, and to be merry with him, who accordingly went with some few Musketeeres, and
were merry, in the meane time a company of Rogues, who lay in ambush for them, rusht in and cut them all off. Captaine Sterlings Corps was brought to Towne yesterday morning. The last weeke a Lieutenant M. Donell a Scotchman, was shot to death for killing a woman which hee met in the streets w • o gave him ill Language, whereupon • ee drew his Sword and runne her thorow. And one of your Countrey-men, a Gloucester shire man escaped his necke very narrowly, for laying downe his Armes, and denying to take them up againe, untill he had received his pay; I saw him on the Ladder and ready to be turnd off, but presently there was a cry of a pardon (but indeed there was no such intention) wherupon the Soldiers instantly brought him down and carryed him away in despight of the Provost Martiall and his Traine; there were swords drawne about it, but no hurt done. The Souldiers begin to very insolent for want of pay. Your good friend Charles Dodeswell is
principall Secretary to the Earle of Ormond, his predecessour Mr. Smith is gone into Rebellion.

The Blessings of God (Brother) unto sinful man are infinite, and the meanes by which hee is pleased to assist and deliver his children from imminent danger, are most incomprehensible unto the dull capacity of fraile man. Witnesse his often deliverances to our poore distressed Brethren here in Ireland, whom his mercy hath so often delivered from the jawes of death and destruction, and from the bloud-thirsty persecution of the insolent and cruell enemy. Nay even when they seemed lost, and had given themselves over as a prey unto their malice, then hath it pleased Almighty God to raise unto them most unexpected meanes for their deliverance, the faithfull and Religious Scotchmen to visit the Neighbouring Brothers in the depth of their calamity who with the hazard of their own lives and fortunes, did endeavour to asswage the swelling enemy, and to revenge their
wrongs with the danger of their owne safety. What hath beene a long time expected and wished, is now put into practice and execution, and about the 16. of May General Lesley was shipt with 6000 foot, provided for the succour and reliefe of Ireland, and 1000. horse were also at the same time on ship-boord, which were to be disciplind and commanded by Sir William Belfore late Lieutenant of the Tower of London, unto whose pious and Religious proceedings God of his great and infinite mercy send happy and and deserving successe, so that Jerusalem againe may flourish, and that we may againe enjoy peace within the walls of Sion, and behold all her now ruind and demolisht buildings new built and beautifull.

div.head: A List of the Field-Officers chose ad appoited for the Irish Expedition, by the Committee at Guildhall London, for the Regiments of 5000. Foot, and 500. Horse, Under the Command of Philip Lord Wharton, Baron of Scarborough, lord Generall for Ireland.

list.head: Fourth troop Liev. Colonel Io. Hurry.
Foot Companies.

His Captain Edward Massy.
His Ensigne Oliver Cromwell.

His Ensigne Ed. Greene.
